prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity requirement: We request a CO(3-2) line sensitivity of 4.09 mJy in order to detect the peak emission with 10 sigma. The expected values of peak fluxes evaluated from H alpha flux from 40.95 mJy.
Angular resolution: Our main target is a giant molecular cloud and a giant molecular association. Their typical scale ranges from ~10 pc to ~100 pc. We therefore require the angular resolution of 1.00". The largest angular scale of interest is 5.00". They can be achieved with the 12-m array only.
Correlator setup: Since the velocity widths of our target is expected as 175 km/s from the line width of H alpha emission line obtained from SDSS. We need the velocity resolution of 20 km/s in Band 7. We use the FDM correlator mode of 1875 MHz bandwidth and 976.563 kHz channnel spacing with a spectral averaging facgtor of 4 in Baseband-1. This wide bandwidth is needed to determine the continuum level accurately around a relatively broad emission line. The remaining 3 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wider-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 3 basebands. The frequency center of Baseband-3 is selected to cover the HCO+ emission line, but we do not necessarily need to detect this line. Baseband-2 and Baseband-4 cover the continuum emission.

Sensitivity requirement: We request a CO(3-2) line sensitivity of 2.07 mJy in order to detect the peak emission with 10 sigma. The expected values of peak fluxes evaluated from H alpha flux from 20.73 mJy.
Angular resolution: Our main target is a giant molecular cloud and a giant molecular association. Their typical scale ranges from ~10 pc to ~100 pc. We therefore require the angular resolution of 1.00". The largest angular scale of interest is 5.00". They can be achieved with the 12-m array only.
Correlator setup: Since the velocity widths of our target is expected as 160 km/s from the line width of H alpha emission line obtained from SDSS. We need the velocity resolution of 20 km/s in Band 7. We use the FDM correlator mode of 1875 MHz bandwidth and 976.563 kHz channnel spacing with a spectral averaging facgtor of 4. This wide bandwidth is needed to determine the continuum level accurately around a relatively broad emission line. The remaining 3 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wider-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 3 basebands. The frequency center of Baseband-3 is selected to cover the HCO+ emission line, but we do not necessarily need to detect this line. Baseband-2 and Baseband-4 cover the continuum emission.

Sensitivity requirement: We request a CO(3-2) line sensitivity of 1.17 mJy in order to detect the peak emission with 10 sigma. The expected values of peak fluxes evaluated from H alpha flux from 11.66 mJy.
Angular resolution: Our main target is a giant molecular cloud and a giant molecular association. Their typical scale ranges from ~10 pc to ~100 pc. We therefore require the angular resolution of 1.00". The largest angular scale of interest is 5.00". They can be achieved with the 12-m array only. Since a FoV of the 12 m Array at the center of the galaxy cannot cover the whole galaxy, two FoVs are requested.
Correlator setup: Since the velocity widths of our target is expected as 190 km/s from the line width of H alpha emission line obtained from SDSS. We need the velocity resolution of 20 km/s in Band 7. We use the FDM correlator mode of 1875 MHz bandwidth and 976.563 kHz channnel spacing with a spectral averaging facgtor of 4. This wide bandwidth is needed to determine the continuum level accurately around a relatively broad emission line. The remaining 3 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wider-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 3 basebands. The frequency center of Baseband-3 is selected to cover the HCO+ emission line, but we do not necessarily need to detect this line. Baseband-2 and Baseband-4 cover the continuum emission.

Sensitivity requirement: We request a CO(3-2) line sensitivity of 1.44 mJy in order to detect the peak emission with 10 sigma. The expected values of peak fluxes evaluated from their H alpha flux from 14.39 mJy.
Angular resolution: Our main target is a giant molecular cloud and a giant molecular association. Their typical scale ranges from ~10 pc to ~100 pc. We therefore require the angular resolution of 1.00". The largest angular scale of interest is 5.00". They can be achieved with the 12-m array only.
Correlator setup: Since the velocity widths of our target is expected as 150 km/s from the line width of H alpha emission line obtained from SDSS. We need the velocity resolution of 20 km/s in Band 7. We use the FDM correlator mode of 1875 MHz bandwidth and 976.563 kHz channnel spacing with a spectral averaging facgtor of 4.This wide bandwidth is needed to determine the continuum level accurately around a relatively broad emission line. The remaining 3 basebands are used to detect the continuum emission. Since a wider-coverage setting is preferred for detecting the continuum emission, we select a bandwidth of 1875 MHz also for these 3 basebands. The frequency center of Baseband-3 is selected to cover the HCO+ emission line, but we do not necessarily need to detect this line. Baseband-2 and Baseband-4 cover the continuum emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In order to understand the nature of building blocks of galaxies in early universe, we have selected a sample of “genuine irregular galaxies (GIGs)” in nearby universe from the catalogs of the SDSS irregular galaxies. These GIGs are isolated galaxies without regular structures (spheroid, bulge, disk, bar, spiral arm, and nucleus). They are considered to be relics of the building block of galaxies in nearby universe since they are low stellar mass and chemically primitive. They will offer an unique window to the properties of star formation in the early stages of galaxy formation not caused by galaxy interaction and/or merger. Here we propose a CO(3-2) observation of 4 GIGs at distances of ~ 30 Mpc to probe their structure and kinematics of molecular gas. Through this observation, we clarify how GIGs evolve into normal galaxies.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Research Center for Space and Cosmic Evolution, National University Corporation Ehime University
Research Center for Space and Cosmic Evolution, National University Corporation Ehime University
